DOC.HEADLINE: 24 CITY DRAMA. DIRECTED BY JIA ZHANG-KE. WITH JOAN CHEN, ZHAO TAO. IN MANDARIN WITH ENGLISH SUBTITLES.

TEXT.P: Jia Zhang-Ke is, like it or not, one of the world's most important directors.

Those that like it admire his carefully made films (especially "Platform" and "The World") and original approach to observing a China that might be losing a part of its identity as it transitions to Western economic and cultural values. Those that don't would rather watch paint dry than another one of his bore-fests.

"24 City" won't change the minds of detractors -- it is his most painfully slow yet -- but it might change the minds of his supporters, including this critic, for Jia attempts something that is, in the end, unforgivable.

Purportedly a documentary of a state-run factory closing near Chengdu City and how it affects its former workers, "24 City" mixes honest interviews of real people who worked at the factory for decades with interviews of actors playing former workers. The trouble is, Jia does not indicate which is documentary and which is acting (only the San Francisco actress Joan Chen, playing, no kidding, a factory worker who looks like Joan Chen, would be recognizable to a sizable portion of Western viewers).
In other words, half of this movie -- four of the nine people interviewed are actors -- is a big lie.

Why does Jia do this? The film has lovely, almost fetishistic images of the factory, courtesy of cinematographer Yu Lik-wai, that recalls the industrial images in the excellent 2006 documentary "Manufactured Landscapes."

It is also at times a touching portrait of a culture in flux. One woman, now in her 50s and out of work, heartbreakingly observes, "If you have something to do, you age more slowly." She, of course, has nothing to do and feels her life slipping away.

Such truth makes it all the more embarrassing when an actor tries to capture the same emotion -- and this is no knock against the actors. It's just that it comes off lame by comparison, and takes the viewer completely out of the film.
